comment: I'd say that he spends most of his lectures discussing proofs and doesn't do enough practice problems. His lecture slides are abysmal and don't clearly convey what he's trying to teach, so most of the time he writes on the board. Homework is also six problems and exams are equally brutal. In order to actually pass you need to read the book as well.

May get better, but right now I would avoid Dr. Niloy. I think it comes down to a super knowledgeable person who simply cannot teach the content or inspire others. I have learned more from YouTube than his lectures, but lecture materials are our "primary learning materials." However, the -optional- textbook is where homework and tests come from.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The entire class time is spent on derivations to formulas with no real chance for application. The lecture slides are also a cluttered mess of derivations that must be sifted through to find anything helpful. Prepare to teach yourself.

comment: He has been the worst professor I have taken in my entire life. He will derive every aspect of thermodynamics during class, and he will never finish his complicated examples. His tests and homework are extremely convoluted and not helpful at all. It is clear that he is smart, but that he has NO idea how to teach, talk, or explain to students.

Niloy "knows" the information, but can not TEACH the information. There have been multiple lectures that goes over the same proofs, but without any example on how to use the proofs. Exams make up a large chunk of grade, but not enough practice/direction/feedback to prepare. Worst part: no methodology is provided for such a broad/tough topic. AVOID.

Lectures consisted of hour long proofs that did not correlate to the exams whatsoever. Exams were loosely based on homework problems but with multiplied difficulty. Exams were too long so very few students finished the entire exam to completion. Very difficult to follow during lectures but it really didn't do any good to even try. I would beware.

comment: Lectures don't help on exams. Only 2 exams, small amount of homework, maybe extra credit but he's taking too long to grade to know before withdrawal/drop. No formula sheet in thermodynamics. Proof that aren't applicable to exam and exams are not like anything he teaches. Rarely does example problems. Doesn't post slides till after lecture.

Probably the worst professor I've ever had. Graded on 2 exams and few homework. What he teaches in class is nothing like the hw and exams. He looks like he's trying to convince you of the material and you can tell this is probably his first year teaching. Hw and exam problems are from textbook. Doesn't post notes til after he lectures on the board.

He's really smart and knows what he's teaching, but he's not good at conveying that information clearly. I don't think he's been teaching long. Also what he goes over in class is nothing like the homework or tests.

I wouldn't risk it. It's the middle of the semester and we still have no grades on anything. His HW questions ≠ Lecture material. He pretty much only does proofs as a lecture. NO formula sheet, only 50 pages of tables that you have to print yourself. Pretty sure this is his first semester ever teaching. Be prepared to teach yourself via YouTube.
